HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE, Dec. 12, 1969

Benton Named Homewood Dean;
Kimball to Return to Research
Dr. George S. Benton will replace Allyn W. Kimball as Dean of
the Faculty of Arts and Sciences
at the end of this academic year.
The appointment, effective July
1, was announced Tuesday by
Lincoln Gordon. Dean Kimball
asked to be relieved of the deanship approximately one month
ago. He says that he wants to
return to teaching and research in
the university's Department of Biostatistics, where he formerly served
as chairman.
Dr. Benton is currently a Professor of Meteorology and Chairman
of the Department of Earth and
Planetary Sciences. He has been .a
member of the Hopkins faculty
since 1948.
Gordon called Benton "a scholar
and administrator of well-deserved
international reputation, who has

made important contributions to
scientific knowledge." Gordon
added that Hopkins was "indeed
fortunate to have found within its
ranks a man so eminently qualified
to assume the deanship."
Difficult Decision
Benton was approached with the
offer three weeks ago,and decided
to accept the appointment last
week. He states that the decision
to accept the post was 'a difficult
one for him to make. "Someone in
my position gives up an awful lot,"
when taking an administrative
post, he said. Benton believes he
will be able to devote very little
time to his academic specialty
while he serves as Dean.
Kimball said that when he accepted the post of Dean, he
thought that he would be able to
maintain some activity in his role

as professor. He found, however,
that this was impossible during
his four years in Gilman Hall.
Kimball estimates that he put in
seventy to eighty hours per week
in his job. Gordon referred to the
deanship as "a man-killing job."
Benton is familiar with the duties of a top-level administrator, if
not with those of the Homewood
deanship. For three years, until
last September, he was director of
Research Laboratories of the
Environmental Science Services
Administration of the Department
of Commerce while on leave from
Hopkins. From the ESSA research
laboratories in Boulder, Colorado,
he directed research efforts in the
environmental sciences at fifteen
laboratories throughout the country.

By STEPHEN SHRIVER
Eleventh hour special negotiations and
strong pressure from the Black community of Baltimore narrowly averted a
strike by non-professional employees at
the Johns Hopkins Hospital.
A compromise contract agreement was
reached at 2:08 a.m. Tuesday, December 9th, between Local 1199E, which represents the 1472 workers in the bargaining unit, and the Hopkins Hospital
administration.
Both sides in the dispute had been
called into special negotiating sessions
by Federal mediator Martin Komoric
over the weekend in an attempt to reach
a settlement before the union's strike
deadline, set for 6 a.m.Wednesday, December 10. 1199E Area Director Fred
Punch said he expected the union members to ratify the contract"overwhelmingly" in a vote scheduled for Thursday,
December 11.

an hour, to $2.35 an hour effective December 1, 1970, and to $2.55 an hour a
year later.

December Moratorium:'Take it Home'
By MICHAEL WEISSMAN
This month's three-day Moratorium,
slated for December 12, 13, and 24, will
focus on grass-roots action on the local
level.
While at home during the winter vacation, students will be urged to "Take
the Moratorium Home for Christmas."
The organizers of the Moratorium, led
by Sam Brown, suggest that college students canvass neighborhoods, distribute
leaflets to shoppers,organize high school
students, send delegates to petition elected officials, and hold vigils or processions on Christmas Eve.
Mr. Brown, to emphasize the moratorium's need for local action said, "It
would be a tragedy to miss the opportunity to carry the anti-war movement
from our university communities to our
home towns. The work necessary to end
the war in Vietnam cannot be restricted to the areas where we have already
been active."
Town meetings are being held in
twenty-six cities across the country.
These meetings will be held in conjunction with the Coalition on National Prio-

rites and Military Spending. The theme
of these assemblies will be "Local Needs
and Military Spending."

That Old Christmas Feeling
is Here Again
The Christmas season is upon us again, and with it go the usual expressions of peace and good will to all men. The traditional concept of the
season is one of conviviality, reflection, joy and hopes of a better time to
come.
Unfortunately, the Christian tendencies of this nation are rapidly falling
before the onslaught of a vast politicization of its minority groups and the
equally great shift of the government's emphasis from control to repression
and from action to reaction. Instead of providing the leadership of this
nation that its citizens expect, the Federal government is becoming more
and more entwined in 'extra-curricular' activities--such as counting and
comparing the number of pro-war and anti-war letters it receives—which
serve only to divide the nation further and not reach any conclusive
answers.
Vice President Agnew's remarks here in Baltimore are, as usual, relevant
to this point. After discarding his prepared speech, in which he took a long
look at American education, he delivered ten minutes of off-the-cuff
remarks aimed, once again, at demonstrators. "Where a majority of
people," he said, "has spoken in a free election, it is not salutary...to
resort to this constant harangue on the campus and streets." Nixon's 1968
plurality has now become a majority.
What the Vice President continually fails to ask himself is why minorities
are taking to the streets and to the campuses. This country, more than any
other, has traditionally been made up of minorities, and these minority
interests have traditionally been forced to take account of each other.
The difference now is that, unlike the Italians and the Poles and the Irish,
neither the young nor the Negroes are considered legitimate minority
groups. They are thought of as dissidents, and whereas a minority interest
is something to be dealt with, dissidence is equated with anarchy and
subversion.
The ironic aspect of Mr. Agnew's remarks is that the prepared speech
which he released to the press had a.completely different ring to it, and,
had it been used, might have gone a long way toward showing some groups
that the administration really is interested in tackling some of its major
problems in a positive manner. In that speech he said, "If we are not going
to have revolutionary look at our institutions of education." He also noted
that the government should consider changing the institutions to make
them "Fit the public rather than make the public fit the institutions."
Of course, it must be remembered that the speech was not delivered.
In other areas, too, Christmas tidings are equally bleak. It is becoming
evident that the running battle between the Black Panthers and the
nation's police departments has a very interested onlooker in the person of
Attorney General- Mitchell, and that harassment of the Panthers is rapidly
changing into a sophisticated attempt to eradicate the party through
violent means.
The. tax bill issue which is presently being fought out in Congress is
degenerating into a sharp political battle, the results of which are likely to
cut Federal spending in the domestic sector even more, and drive the
inflation even higher.
And, on the war front, indications are that the President's next withdrawal will again only involve 35,000 troops and that the level of the
fighting will not lessen appreciably. By all admissions, the Paris peace talks
are deadlocked and not reaching any solutions.
Merry Christmas—and a happy new decade.

The Department of Physics has recently announced major revisions in its

sole exception to this rule in Electromagnetic Theory, which is still a fullyear course.

in Astrophysic. Also, all the old lab
courses have been consolidated into one
full-year course to be taken by Juniors.

being offered for non-Physical science
majors. A General Physics for Biology majors is planned. Also new are
a course in Astronomy and a course in
Concepts In Physics and Mathematics,

prerequisites.

the picture.

two semester course in Mathematical

courses required of Physics majors.

intend to imply the Math Department

their orientation is towards the theoretical, or "philosophical" aspects of

That Old Christmas Feeling
is Here Again
The Christmas season is upon us again, and with it go the usual expressions of peace and good will to all men. The traditional concept of the
season is one of conviviality, reflection, joy and hopes of a better time to
come.
Unfortunately, the Christian tendencies of this nation are rapidly falling
before the onslaught of a vast politicization of its minority groups and the
equally great shift of the government's emphasis from control to repression
and from action to reaction. Instead of providing the leadership of this
nation that its citizens expect, the Federal government is becoming more
and more entwined in 'extra-curricular' activities--such as counting and
comparing the number of pro-war and anti-war letters it receives—which
serve only to divide the nation further and not reach any conclusive
answers.
Vice President Agnew's remarks here in Baltimore are, as usual, relevant
to this point. After discarding his prepared speech, in which he took a long
look at American education, he delivered ten minutes of off-the-cuff
remarks aimed, once again, at demonstrators. "Where a majority of
people," he said, "has spoken in a free election, it is not salutary...to
resort to this constant harangue on the campus and streets." Nixon's 1968
plurality has now become a majority.
What the Vice President continually fails to ask himself is why minorities
are taking to the streets and to the campuses. This country, more than any
other, has traditionally been made up of minorities, and these minority
interests have traditionally been forced to take account of each other.
The difference now is that, unlike the Italians and the Poles and the Irish,
neither the young nor the Negroes are considered legitimate minority
groups. They are thought of as dissidents, and whereas a minority interest
is something to be dealt with, dissidence is equated with anarchy and
subversion.
The ironic aspect of Mr. Agnew's remarks is that the prepared speech
which he released to the press had a.completely different ring to it, and,
had it been used, might have gone a long way toward showing some groups
that the administration really is interested in tackling some of its major
problems in a positive manner. In that speech he said, "If we are not going
to have revolutionary look at our institutions of education." He also noted
that the government should consider changing the institutions to make
them "Fit the public rather than make the public fit the institutions."
Of course, it must be remembered that the speech was not delivered.
In other areas, too, Christmas tidings are equally bleak. It is becoming
evident that the running battle between the Black Panthers and the
nation's police departments has a very interested onlooker in the person of
Attorney General- Mitchell, and that harassment of the Panthers is rapidly
changing into a sophisticated attempt to eradicate the party through
violent means.
The. tax bill issue which is presently being fought out in Congress is
degenerating into a sharp political battle, the results of which are likely to
cut Federal spending in the domestic sector even more, and drive the
inflation even higher.
And, on the war front, indications are that the President's next withdrawal will again only involve 35,000 troops and that the level of the
fighting will not lessen appreciably. By all admissions, the Paris peace talks
are deadlocked and not reaching any solutions.
Merry Christmas—and a happy new decade.

Panthers: L.A...
In the aftermath of a four-hour gun battle Monday between 300 Los Angeles policemen and members of the
Black Panther Party, many community and state-wide
leaders have linked this case with a national plan aimed
at wiping out the Panther Party.
"This is part of a national plan of political repression
against the Panthers," said State Senator Mervyn Dymally, who represents the South Central area of Los
Angeles. "Look at the Eastern cities; this is not an isolated incident."
Two Panther leaders were killed in Chicago last week
when police raided their apartment looking for weapons.
They were the 27th and 28th Panthers to be shot by the
police in the last two years. Last month in Baltimore
four Panthers were jailed on conspiracy charges and
traffic violations.
Police in Los Angeles said that there was no connection between their raid and the events in other cities.
Their raid began about 330 a.m. Monday as the police
first cordoned off a 16 block area before moving in on
the Panthers headquarters. According to a department
spokesman, the squad announced that they had warrants
to search the building. After receiving no answer, they
said they kicked down the door and were met by a volley
of bullets wounding 2 policemen.
Three hundred officers then spent the night exchanging
sporadic fire with the Panthers. They began lobbing tear
gas canisters into the building and in a space of an hour
flushed out 11 Panthers. The raid was conducted, according to the police, in search of illegal weapons and two
Panthers wanted on assault charges. Said one in the
crowd, "They aren't moving against the Black Panthers
alone, they're moving against the whole black nation.
Anyone who can't see this is a racist thing is crazy."

Coed Quiverings
The Task Force on Coeducation issued a recommendation this week that the question of allowing girls' admission to the freshman class next year be reconsidered.
Previously, President Gordon suggested, and the Board
of Trustees approved, that only sophomore and junior
transfer women be admitted to Hopkins in September.
The Admissions Office has yet to begin active recruitment of female transfer students. About 150 girls
In the last month have sent in written requests for information pertaining to admission. The Office said it will
not begin recruitment until the decision of whether or
not to allow in freshmen women is made.
There are currently four plans to house the women.
One is to have them live off-campus, and is considered
undesireable. Another plan is to redo either two freshmen or upper class dorms to facilitate the women.
Changing two freshmen dorms would cost about $40,000,
the upper class dorns would be substantially more. A
final idea is to house the girls in Wolman Hall, displacing
some of the grad students.
In order to pay for the cost of coeducation, President
Gordon said last week that future undergraduate classes
will be expanded to about 600 students, 150-200 of them
women.
